security: Disclosing Jaffe’s prior cooperation with the FBI and CIA could damage his reputation and future opportunities. Mentioning that the British were “given much of the Nosenko debriefings” could also have a detrimental effect on relations between intelligence agencies, while acknowledging the Agency's attempts to 'pacify Jaffe with the statement contained in the Colby letter' would give information on how the CIA deals with public relations and the statements they provide to individuals who are concerned about the Agency.
summary: This report details Sam Jaffe's past relationships with the FBI and CIA, including his role as an informant and his contact with the KGB, as well as addressing Jaffe's belief that the CIA passed derogatory information to his employers.
summary_one_paragraph: This document provides an overview of Sam Jaffe's history with U.S. intelligence agencies, noting his prior role as an FBI informant from 1958-1960 and meetings with the CIA's Domestic Contact Division in New York. The report also details Jaffe’s interactions with the KGB while in Moscow, including allegations from defector Nosenko and later reassurances that Jaffe was not considered a paid agent. Furthermore, the report addresses Jaffe's concerns that the CIA negatively influenced his employment, referencing a letter from Mr. Colby denying any unauthorized release of information and confirming that his departure from ABC was not related to CIA actions.
title: Sam Jaffe
